elements.content: Molecule-based solid-state materials with long lifetimes could enable longer migration distances for excitons, which are beneficial for vast applications in optoelectronic field. Herein, we report a hexanuclear zinc cluster based MOF exhibits highly enhanced phosphorescence about 2 orders of magnitude in comparison with the pristine phosphor ligand. The combination of both experimental and computational results suggest that the {Zn6} cluster is very important for adjusting molecular conformations, packing arrangement, and photophysical properties of the organic phosphor ligands within the MOF matrix. Optoelectronic measurements reveal that the MOF-modified electrode is catalytically active to hydrogen evolution under light irradiation in neutral solution. Thus, our study provide an effective way to achieve low-cost metal-based phosphorescence MOF, expanding its further optoelectronic applications.
elements.clean_text: Molecule-based solid-state materials with long lifetimes could enable longer migration distances for excitons, which are beneficial for vast applications in optoelectronic field. Herein, we report a hexanuclear zinc cluster based MOF exhibits highly enhanced phosphorescence about 2 orders of magnitude in comparison with the pristine phosphor ligand. The combination of both experimental and computational results suggest that the {Zn6} cluster is very important for adjusting molecular conformations, packing arrangement, and photophysical properties of the organic phosphor ligands within the MOF matrix. Optoelectronic measurements reveal that the MOF-modified electrode is catalytically active to hydrogen evolution under light irradiation in neutral solution. Thus, our study provide an effective way to achieve low-cost metal-based phosphorescence MOF, expanding its further optoelectronic applications.

elements.content: Hexanuclear zinc cluster based MOF exhibits highly enhanced phosphorescence about 2 orders of magnitude larger than that with the pristine phosphor ligand. Optoelectronic measurements reveal that the MOF-modified electrode is catalytically active to hydrogen evolution under light irradiation in neutral water solution.
elements.clean_text: Hexanuclear zinc cluster based MOF exhibits highly enhanced phosphorescence about 2 orders of magnitude larger than that with the pristine phosphor ligand. Optoelectronic measurements reveal that the MOF-modified electrode is catalytically active to hydrogen evolution under light irradiation in neutral water solution.

elements.content: Materials with room-temperature phosphorescence (RTP) character have caused extensive concern due to their fascinating photophysical phenomenon and potential applications in bioimaging, photo dynamic therapy, security protection, and so on. To date, most RTP materials are typically limited to noble metal (such as Pt, Ir, and Ru) based organometallic complexes. However, their scarcity, high cost, poor structural stability, and relative short lifetime have hindered the development of the phosphorescence materials. Thus, the construction of new material with desired phosphorescence and tunability as well as stable structure still remain challenging.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Materials with room-temperature phosphorescence (RTP) character have caused extensive concern due to their fascinating photophysical phenomenon and potential applications in bioimaging, photo dynamic therapy, security protection, and so on. To date, most RTP materials are typically limited to noble metal (such as Pt, Ir, and Ru) based organometallic complexes. However, their scarcity, high cost, poor structural stability, and relative short lifetime have hindered the development of the phosphorescence materials. Thus, the construction of new material with desired phosphorescence and tunability as well as stable structure still remain challenging.

elements.content: Very recently, prominent progress has been made in the design and synthesis of organic RTP materials, several types of methods have been explored such as crystallization, H-aggregation, halogen bonding, host–guest doping, and so on. Meanwhile, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) formed by metal ions/clusters and organic ligands exhibit structure tunability and functionalization. Coordination interactions in MOFs structure can afford more rigidity and promote triplet generation and phosphorescence emission. In this sense, MOFs can be considered as an idealized platform for the construct of multifunctional phosphorescent materials. Therefore, the development of phosphorescent MOFs would afford new types of optical functional materials with outstanding phosphorescent performance.
elements.clean_text: Very recently, prominent progress has been made in the design and synthesis of organic RTP materials, several types of methods have been explored such as crystallization, H-aggregation, halogen bonding, host-guest doping, and so on. Meanwhile, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) formed by metal ions/clusters and organic ligands exhibit structure tunability and functionalization. Coordination interactions in MOFs structure can afford more rigidity and promote triplet generation and phosphorescence emission. In this sense, MOFs can be considered as an idealized platform for the construct of multifunctional phosphorescent materials. Therefore, the development of phosphorescent MOFs would afford new types of optical functional materials with outstanding phosphorescent performance.

elements.content: Meanwhile, the synthesis of cluster based MOFs is of great importance for the application of luminescent sensors, CO2 conversions, cancer therapy, and so on. There are several synthetic strategies for the construction of cluster based systems, among which the selection of organic ligand plays key way to adjust the nuclearity and arrangement of metal clusters. As a derivatives of isophthalic acid phosphorescent ligand, the steric hindrance of ethoxyl group for 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA) ligand has the ability to affect metal ions to form unpredictable clusters. In addition, the intersysterm crossing of EtOIPA ligand will be efficiently enhanced after it is tightly confined in the rigid environment of MOFs through strong coordination bonds. To our knowledge, cluster-based Zn MOFs with persistent RTP performance has rarely been reported.
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, the synthesis of cluster based MOFs is of great importance for the application of luminescent sensors, CO2 conversions, cancer therapy, and so on. There are several synthetic strategies for the construction of cluster based systems, among which the selection of organic ligand plays key way to adjust the nuclearity and arrangement of metal clusters. As a derivatives of isophthalic acid phosphorescent ligand, the steric hindrance of ethoxyl group for 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA) ligand has the ability to affect metal ions to form unpredictable clusters. In addition, the intersysterm crossing of EtOIPA ligand will be efficiently enhanced after it is tightly confined in the rigid environment of MOFs through strong coordination bonds. To our knowledge, cluster-based Zn MOFs with persistent RTP performance has rarely been reported.

elements.content: On the basis of the above considerations, herein, a Zn cluster based MOF, [Zn3(EtOIPA)2(μ3-OH)2]·(H2O) (Zn-EtOIPA), has been synthesized and investigated. The as-prepared MOF exhibits highly enhanced room-temperature phosphorescence in comparison with the pristine EtOIPA crystals owning to the strong coordination bonds between hexanuclear zinc clusters and EtOIPA molecules. The denser crystal packing of MOF structure allows substantial overlap of the π–π stacking and thus boosting the phosphorescence performance. Furthermore, the optoelectronic performances of Zn-EtOIPA have also been investigated.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the above considerations, herein, a Zn cluster based MOF, [Zn3(EtOIPA)2(μ3-OH)2]⋅(H2O) (Zn-EtOIPA), has been synthesized and investigated. The as-prepared MOF exhibits highly enhanced room-temperature phosphorescence in comparison with the pristine EtOIPA crystals owning to the strong coordination bonds between hexanuclear zinc clusters and EtOIPA molecules. The denser crystal packing of MOF structure allows substantial overlap of the π-π stacking and thus boosting the phosphorescence performance. Furthermore, the optoelectronic performances of Zn-EtOIPA have also been investigated.

elements.content: Analytically pure Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, KOH and 5-ethoxyisophthalic acid were commercial available. Crystal data for Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA were obtained from Oxford SuperNova diffractometer with molybdenum target. The crystal structure was solved by SHELXS-2014. The crystal data for Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA were listed in Table S1. The CIF file of Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA (CCDC Nos. 1895025 and 1895026) can be downloaded via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Procedures

Analytically pure Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, KOH and 5-ethoxyisophthalic acid were commercial available. Crystal data for Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA were obtained from Oxford SuperNova diffractometer with molybdenum target. The crystal structure was solved by SHELXS-2014. The crystal data for Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA were listed in Table S1. The CIF file of Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA (CCDC Nos. 1895025 and 1895026) can be downloaded via http://www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/conts/retrieving.html.

elements.content: PXRD patterns were collected on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer with copper target with 2θ in the range of 5–50° at 40 kV, 30 mA. The IR spectra were measured from 4000–400 cm–1 on a Nicolet 6700 (Thermo) with bromatum kalium pellets. TGA data were collected by a SII EXStar6000 TG/DTA6300 thermal analyzer in the range of 25–800 °C (with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1) under a N2 stream.
elements.clean_text: PXRD patterns were collected on a Bruker D8-ADVANCE X-ray diffractometer with copper target with 2θ in the range of 5-50° at 40 kV, 30 mA. The IR spectra were measured from 4000-400 cm-1 on a Nicolet 6700 (Thermo) with bromatum kalium pellets. TGA data were collected by a SII EXStar6000 TG/DTA6300 thermal analyzer in the range of 25-800 °C (with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1) under a N2 stream.

elements.content: Photographs of MOF powder under 365 nm UV light and daylight were captured by a Canon EOS 700D digital camera (ISO: 400, under automatic exposure mode). The morphology for Zn-EtOIPA was observed by Sigma 500 SEM. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra and phosphorescence decay curves were performed by Edinburgh FLS1000 fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a xenon arc lamp and a microsecond flash lamp at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Photographs of MOF powder under 365 nm UV light and daylight were captured by a Canon EOS 700D digital camera (ISO: 400, under automatic exposure mode). The morphology for Zn-EtOIPA was observed by Sigma 500 SEM. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra and phosphorescence decay curves were performed by Edinburgh FLS1000 fluorescence spectrometer equipped with a xenon arc lamp and a microsecond flash lamp at room temperature.

elements.content: Optoelectronic properties were conducted by a Chenhua CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. Using Zn-EtOIPA powder modified indium tin oxide (ITO) electrode (with a working area of 1.0 cm2), Ag/AgCl, and platinum wire as working, reference, and counter electrodes, respectively. The electrolyte is 0.5 M sodium sulfate aqueous solution. The system was conducted in a quartz glass reactor ca. 50 cm3 and irradiated by a 300 W xenon lamp. The cyclic voltammograms (CV) and linear-sweep voltammograms (LSV) were measured with a scan rate of 0.05 V/s under dark and light illumination. Transient current-density–time characteristics and constant potential electrolysis curves were tested at bias potential of 0 and −1 V vs Ag/AgCl, respectively. Evolved H2 were analyzed by an Agilent GC 7890A online gas chromatograph.
elements.clean_text: Optoelectronic properties were conducted by a Chenhua CHI 660E electrochemical workstation. Using Zn-EtOIPA powder modified indium tin oxide (ITO) electrode (with a working area of 1.0 cm2), Ag/AgCl, and platinum wire as working, reference, and counter electrodes, respectively. The electrolyte is 0.5 M sodium sulfate aqueous solution. The system was conducted in a quartz glass reactor ca. 50 cm3 and irradiated by a 300 W xenon lamp. The cyclic voltammograms (CV) and linear-sweep voltammograms (LSV) were measured with a scan rate of 0.05 V/s under dark and light illumination. Transient current-density-time characteristics and constant potential electrolysis curves were tested at bias potential of 0 and -1 V vs Ag/AgCl, respectively. Evolved H2 were analyzed by an Agilent GC 7890A online gas chromatograph.

elements.content: A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 0.1 mmol, 21.0 mg), Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 22.0 mg), KOH (0.1 mmol, 5.6 mg), and H2O (15 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 72 h, and then cooled to 25 °C over 1 day. Pale-yellow block crystals of Zn-EtOIPA can be isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn-EtOIPA Crystals

A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 0.1 mmol, 21.0 mg), Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol, 22.0 mg), KOH (0.1 mmol, 5.6 mg), and H2O (15 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 72 h, and then cooled to 25 °C over 1 day. Pale-yellow block crystals of Zn-EtOIPA can be isolated.

elements.content: A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 1 mmol, 210 mg) and H2O (8 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 12 h, and then cooled to 25 °C naturally. Colorless block crystals of EtOIPA can be isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of EtOIPA Crystals

A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 1 mmol, 210 mg) and H2O (8 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 12 h, and then cooled to 25 °C naturally. Colorless block crystals of EtOIPA can be isolated.

elements.content: All calculations were implemented by Dmol3 module in Material Studio. The configurations are as follows: PW91, GGA, DNP, ECP SCF (converged within 1.0 × 10–5 hartree atom–1), Brillouin zone sample (1 × 1 × 1 k-points).
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Structure Calculations

All calculations were implemented by Dmol3 module in Material Studio. The configurations are as follows: PW91, GGA, DNP, ECP SCF (converged within 1.0 × 10-5 hartree atom-1), Brillouin zone sample (1 × 1 × 1 k-points).

elements.content: Zn-EtOIPA and the pristine phosphor ligand EtOIPA in crystal state can be obtained under hydrothermal conditions. PXRD curves (Figure S1) indicate that the experiment diffraction peaks match well with those of the simulated pattern, confirming the high purity of the Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA samples. The IR spectra of Zn-EtOIPA (Figure S2a) shows the broad bands at ∼3400 cm–1, which is attributed to the lattice water molecules. The observation of strong band at 1628 and 1383 cm–1 was assigned to asymmetric and symmetric vibration of carboxylate groups, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S2b) exhibits that Zn-EtOIPA can be stable up to about 420 °C, demonstrating high stability of such MOF. SEM image (Figure S3) clearly shows the similar morphologies of Zn-EtOIPA.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Zn-EtOIPA and the pristine phosphor ligand EtOIPA in crystal state can be obtained under hydrothermal conditions. PXRD curves (Figure S1) indicate that the experiment diffraction peaks match well with those of the simulated pattern, confirming the high purity of the Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA samples. The IR spectra of Zn-EtOIPA (Figure S2a) shows the broad bands at ~3400 cm-1, which is attributed to the lattice water molecules. The observation of strong band at 1628 and 1383 cm-1 was assigned to asymmetric and symmetric vibration of carboxylate groups, respectively. Thermogravimetric analysis (Figure S2b) exhibits that Zn-EtOIPA can be stable up to about 420 °C, demonstrating high stability of such MOF. SEM image (Figure S3) clearly shows the similar morphologies of Zn-EtOIPA.

elements.content: Crystal structures for both of Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA were fully determined by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Figure S4a exhibits that molecules of EtOIPA are arranged into a zigzag chain via strong O–H···O hydrogen bonding [O1···O2 2.625 Å, H1···O2 1.389 Å, O1–H1···O2 175.36°] between adjacent carboxylate groups in a head-to-tail mode. 2D layer with ethyl groups hanging on two sides is formed by C–H···O hydrogen bonding [C9···O3 3.300 Å, H9b···O3 2.574 Å, C9–H9b···O3 131.73°] between zigzag chains. These layers are further connected by C–H···O hydrogen bonding [C10···O1 3.795 Å, H10b···O1 3.032 Å, C10–H10b···O1 137.46°] generating a 3D network (Figure S4b). The distance between parallel benzene rings is too long (4.970 Å) to generate intermolecular π···π interactions. In such a 3D network, short contacts around the EtOIPA molecule can provide a rigid environment to confine the molecular vibrations.
elements.clean_text: Crystal structures for both of Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA were fully determined by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Figure S4a exhibits that molecules of EtOIPA are arranged into a zigzag chain via strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding [O1⋅⋅⋅O2 2.625 Å, H1⋅⋅⋅O2 1.389 Å, O1-H1⋅⋅⋅O2 175.36°] between adjacent carboxylate groups in a head-to-tail mode. 2D layer with ethyl groups hanging on two sides is formed by C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding [C9⋅⋅⋅O3 3.300 Å, H9b⋅⋅⋅O3 2.574 Å, C9-H9b⋅⋅⋅O3 131.73°] between zigzag chains. These layers are further connected by C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding [C10⋅⋅⋅O1 3.795 Å, H10b⋅⋅⋅O1 3.032 Å, C10-H10b⋅⋅⋅O1 137.46°] generating a 3D network (Figure S4b). The distance between parallel benzene rings is too long (4.970 Å) to generate intermolecular π⋅⋅⋅π interactions. In such a 3D network, short contacts around the EtOIPA molecule can provide a rigid environment to confine the molecular vibrations.

elements.content: Upon coordination with Zn2+ ions to obtain the organic–metal hybrid Zn-EtOIPA through a hydrothermal synthesis, the deprotonated EtOIPA molecules are ordered via strong coordination bonds. Crystal structure of Zn-EtOIPA is a 3D network based on hexanuclear [Zn6(COO)4(OH)4] cluster ({Zn6}) nodes (a,b) and EtOIPA bridging ligands. The asymmetric unit of Zn-EtOIPA contains three different zinc atoms, two different EtOIPA ligands, two types of μ3-OH–, and one guest water molecule. Zn1 atom is bonded to five O atoms of one hydroxyl group and four different EtOIPA ligands. Zn2 lies in [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry containing four O atoms from two different EtOIPA and two hydroxyl groups. The third type of zinc, Zn3, is bound by one EtOIPA ligand and three hydroxyl groups. The two carboxylate groups in the two ligands display similar bidentate coordination modes. As a result, adjacent {Zn6} clusters are interconnected by a pair of carboxylate groups to form a 1D polymer chain, which is further connected by the EtOIPA ligands result in a 3D porous network (c). Channels of different sizes are occupied by guest water molecules and ethoxyl groups from EtOIPA ligands.
elements.clean_text: Upon coordination with Zn2+ ions to obtain the organic-metal hybrid Zn-EtOIPA through a hydrothermal synthesis, the deprotonated EtOIPA molecules are ordered via strong coordination bonds. Crystal structure of Zn-EtOIPA is a 3D network based on hexanuclear [Zn6(COO)4(OH)4] cluster ({Zn6}) nodes (a,b) and EtOIPA bridging ligands. The asymmetric unit of Zn-EtOIPA contains three different zinc atoms, two different EtOIPA ligands, two types of μ3-OH-, and one guest water molecule. Zn1 atom is bonded to five O atoms of one hydroxyl group and four different EtOIPA ligands. Zn2 lies in [ZnO4] tetrahedral coordination geometry containing four O atoms from two different EtOIPA and two hydroxyl groups. The third type of zinc, Zn3, is bound by one EtOIPA ligand and three hydroxyl groups. The two carboxylate groups in the two ligands display similar bidentate coordination modes. As a result, adjacent {Zn6} clusters are interconnected by a pair of carboxylate groups to form a 1D polymer chain, which is further connected by the EtOIPA ligands result in a 3D porous network (c). Channels of different sizes are occupied by guest water molecules and ethoxyl groups from EtOIPA ligands.

elements.content: Ball-and-stick view of the hexanuclear zinc cluster (a and b) and 3D network (c) of Zn-EtOIPA. π···π supramolecular interactions between two paralleled benzene rings fixed by two clusters (d).
elements.clean_text: 1  Ball-and-stick view of the hexanuclear zinc cluster (a and b) and 3D network (c) of Zn-EtOIPA. π⋅⋅⋅π supramolecular interactions between two paralleled benzene rings fixed by two clusters (d).

elements.content: In the 3D network of Zn-EtOIPA, the EtOIPA molecule displays completely different conformation and arrangement from the free one. The most different feature is that the ethoxyl group hangs on one side of benzene ring in free EtOIPA, while it shows approximately plane conformation in Zn-EtOIPA (Figure S5). Thus, Zn-EtOIPA may have more π···π stacking degree compared with free EtOIPA. In addition, the carboxylic groups has a torsion angle of 27.88° (Figure S6) with benzene rings (5.02° for free EtOIPA), this is larger in contrast with those of free EtOIPA. Such conformations may enhance the production of triplet exciton. In comparison with single metal node in MOF, metal clusters have the ability to hold more directional information by predestined bridging ligands, controlling the overall coordination networks. As shown in d, owing to the structure-directing effect, neighboring parallel EtOIPA molecules in a head-to-tail arrangement are tightly fixed by rigid {Zn6} clusters through coordination bonds. The short interplanar distance of 3.566 Å indicates that strong π···π interactions exist in Zn-EtOIPA. In contrast, the absence of π···π overlap in EtOIPA crystal can originate from the twisty ethoxyl group. The results indicate that the strong coordination bonds between hexanuclear zinc clusters and EtOIPA molecules is powerful to afford a rigid environment to tightly fix the chromophore.
elements.clean_text: In the 3D network of Zn-EtOIPA, the EtOIPA molecule displays completely different conformation and arrangement from the free one. The most different feature is that the ethoxyl group hangs on one side of benzene ring in free EtOIPA, while it shows approximately plane conformation in Zn-EtOIPA (Figure S5). Thus, Zn-EtOIPA may have more π⋅⋅⋅π stacking degree compared with free EtOIPA. In addition, the carboxylic groups has a torsion angle of 27.88° (Figure S6) with benzene rings (5.02° for free EtOIPA), this is larger in contrast with those of free EtOIPA. Such conformations may enhance the production of triplet exciton. In comparison with single metal node in MOF, metal clusters have the ability to hold more directional information by predestined bridging ligands, controlling the overall coordination networks. As shown in d, owing to the structure-directing effect, neighboring parallel EtOIPA molecules in a head-to-tail arrangement are tightly fixed by rigid {Zn6} clusters through coordination bonds. The short interplanar distance of 3.566 Å indicates that strong π⋅⋅⋅π interactions exist in Zn-EtOIPA. In contrast, the absence of π⋅⋅⋅π overlap in EtOIPA crystal can originate from the twisty ethoxyl group. The results indicate that the strong coordination bonds between hexanuclear zinc clusters and EtOIPA molecules is powerful to afford a rigid environment to tightly fix the chromophore.

elements.content: Photoluminescence (PL) spectra and phosphorescence decay curves of pure EtOIPA and Zn-EtOIPA in solid state were performed at ambient temperature. The free EtOIPA in crystalline form presents blue emission peak at 365, 434, and 468 nm with the excitation at 321 nm (a). After coordination with Zn2+ ions through a hydrothermal synthesis, Zn-EtOIPA shows cyan emission at 476 nm excited at 386 nm (b). Insets are the photos of crystal samples radiated by daylight and UV. Measured under phosphorescence mode, the emission peak of EtOIPA at 365 nm is located at the same position, whereas both peaks at 434 and 476 nm increased. In contrast, a large redshift about 100 nm can be observed in Zn-EtOIPA, which presents orange emission peak at 578 nm. The phosphorescence lifetime for EtOIPA is 8.3, 8.5, and 19 μs (c). Those for Zn-EtOIPA at 578 nm was estimated as 1.4 ms (d), which is about 100 times as long as that of the pristine EtOIPA. Compared with the pristine EtOIPA, the hybrid Zn-EtOIPA MOF exhibits longer emission wavelength and lifetime. The distinct redshift can be related to π···π stacking of parallel EtOIPA molecules. The enhanced phosphorescence performance can be stem from the fact that EtOIPA ligands are highly fixed within Zn-EtOIPA matrix. In such a rigid environment, the EtOIPA chromophores are firmly locked between bulky hexanuclear zinc clusters, manifesting an approximatively plane conformation, affording more accident for π···π stacking. Additionally, the PL properties of Zn-EtOIPA under O2 atmosphere and moisture were also measured. It is only found that the PL intensity and lifetime reduced slightly after fumed by moisture (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text: Photoluminescence (PL) spectra and phosphorescence decay curves of pure EtOIPA and Zn-EtOIPA in solid state were performed at ambient temperature. The free EtOIPA in crystalline form presents blue emission peak at 365, 434, and 468 nm with the excitation at 321 nm (a). After coordination with Zn2+ ions through a hydrothermal synthesis, Zn-EtOIPA shows cyan emission at 476 nm excited at 386 nm (b). Insets are the photos of crystal samples radiated by daylight and UV. Measured under phosphorescence mode, the emission peak of EtOIPA at 365 nm is located at the same position, whereas both peaks at 434 and 476 nm increased. In contrast, a large redshift about 100 nm can be observed in Zn-EtOIPA, which presents orange emission peak at 578 nm. The phosphorescence lifetime for EtOIPA is 8.3, 8.5, and 19 μs (c). Those for Zn-EtOIPA at 578 nm was estimated as 1.4 ms (d), which is about 100 times as long as that of the pristine EtOIPA. Compared with the pristine EtOIPA, the hybrid Zn-EtOIPA MOF exhibits longer emission wavelength and lifetime. The distinct redshift can be related to π⋅⋅⋅π stacking of parallel EtOIPA molecules. The enhanced phosphorescence performance can be stem from the fact that EtOIPA ligands are highly fixed within Zn-EtOIPA matrix. In such a rigid environment, the EtOIPA chromophores are firmly locked between bulky hexanuclear zinc clusters, manifesting an approximatively plane conformation, affording more accident for π⋅⋅⋅π stacking. Additionally, the PL properties of Zn-EtOIPA under O2 atmosphere and moisture were also measured. It is only found that the PL intensity and lifetime reduced slightly after fumed by moisture (Figure S7).

elements.content: Normalized PL spectra of EtOIPA (a) and Zn-EtOIPA (b) measured under fluorescence (black) and phosphorescence (red) modes, excited at 321 and 386 nm, respectively. PL decay curves of EtOIPA (c) and Zn-EtOIPA (d) in solid state at room temperature. Insets show the corresponding photographs under daylight and UV (365 nm).
elements.clean_text: 2  Normalized PL spectra of EtOIPA (a) and Zn-EtOIPA (b) measured under fluorescence (black) and phosphorescence (red) modes, excited at 321 and 386 nm, respectively. PL decay curves of EtOIPA (c) and Zn-EtOIPA (d) in solid state at room temperature. Insets show the corresponding photographs under daylight and UV (365 nm).

elements.content: The density functional theory computations (Figure S8) imply that the band gap for Zn-EtOIPA is 2.59 eV (about 478 nm), which match with the fluorescence emission (2.61 eV, 476 nm). The HOMO and LUMO are predominantly dominated by the EtOIPA chromophores. The HOMO–7 is distribute on {Zn6} clusters (a and S9). Around the Fermi level, it can be found that the d orbit of zinc contributed to the electronic densities of state (b). These calculations indicate that the {Zn6} clusters participate the frontier orbital distributions and play an important role in adjusting the luminescence of Zn-EtOIPA.
elements.clean_text: The density functional theory computations (Figure S8) imply that the band gap for Zn-EtOIPA is 2.59 eV (about 478 nm), which match with the fluorescence emission (2.61 eV, 476 nm). The HOMO and LUMO are predominantly dominated by the EtOIPA chromophores. The HOMO-7 is distribute on {Zn6} clusters (a and S9). Around the Fermi level, it can be found that the d orbit of zinc contributed to the electronic densities of state (b). These calculations indicate that the {Zn6} clusters participate the frontier orbital distributions and play an important role in adjusting the luminescence of Zn-EtOIPA.

elements.content: Selected HOMO/LUMO orbitals (a) and electronic densities of state (b) for the profiles based on density functional theory calculations for Zn-EtOIPA.
elements.clean_text: 3  Selected HOMO/LUMO orbitals (a) and electronic densities of state (b) for the profiles based on density functional theory calculations for Zn-EtOIPA.

elements.content: It has been realized that the long lifetime of phosphorescence materials can allow longer exciton diffusion length, generating more free charges, which can be potentially used in a variety of optoelectronic fields. Herein, the photoelectric performances of Zn-EtOIPA were measured in neutral sodium sulfate aqueous solution. Both CV and LSV curves in Figure S10 reveal that Zn-EtOIPA modified electrode is catalytically active to hydrogen evolution under light irradiation in neutral solution. As shown in a, it was observed that Zn-EtOIPA modified electrode exhibits high photocurrent density (−1.2 μA cm–2) when the light source was turned on without applying an external potential. It is about 10 times as high as that without illumination (light off). To explore the robustness of the Zn-EtOIPA modified electrode, long-term constant potential electrolysis was investigated at −1 V vs Ag/AgCl (b). Under these conditions, it generates a constant current density of 71 μA cm–2 under a dark state. In contrast, a dramatic enhancement of the photocurrent density was observed, which increased slowly to a steady state of 78 μA cm–2 under light irradiation. Figure S11 presents the time courses of H2 evolution with Zn-EtOIPA photoanode at biases of −1 V vs Ag/AgCl under light illumination. After soaking in sodium sulfate aqueous solution for 48 h, Zn-EtOIPA maintain it is structure stability as confirmed by PXRD (Figure S12). The results demonstrate here have set a platform for develop phosphorescence MOF materials for potential optoelectronic applications.
elements.clean_text: It has been realized that the long lifetime of phosphorescence materials can allow longer exciton diffusion length, generating more free charges, which can be potentially used in a variety of optoelectronic fields. Herein, the photoelectric performances of Zn-EtOIPA were measured in neutral sodium sulfate aqueous solution. Both CV and LSV curves in Figure S10 reveal that Zn-EtOIPA modified electrode is catalytically active to hydrogen evolution under light irradiation in neutral solution. As shown in a, it was observed that Zn-EtOIPA modified electrode exhibits high photocurrent density (-1.2 μA cm-2) when the light source was turned on without applying an external potential. It is about 10 times as high as that without illumination (light off). To explore the robustness of the Zn-EtOIPA modified electrode, long-term constant potential electrolysis was investigated at -1 V vs Ag/AgCl (b). Under these conditions, it generates a constant current density of 71 μA cm-2 under a dark state. In contrast, a dramatic enhancement of the photocurrent density was observed, which increased slowly to a steady state of 78 μA cm-2 under light irradiation. Figure S11 presents the time courses of H2 evolution with Zn-EtOIPA photoanode at biases of -1 V vs Ag/AgCl under light illumination. After soaking in sodium sulfate aqueous solution for 48 h, Zn-EtOIPA maintain it is structure stability as confirmed by PXRD (Figure S12). The results demonstrate here have set a platform for develop phosphorescence MOF materials for potential optoelectronic applications.

elements.content: Transient current density–time characteristics without bias potential (a) and constant potential electrolysis curves at bias potential of −1 V vs Ag/AgCl (b) for Zn-EtOIPA in 0.5 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution under dark and light illumination.
elements.clean_text: 4  Transient current density-time characteristics without bias potential (a) and constant potential electrolysis curves at bias potential of -1 V vs Ag/AgCl (b) for Zn-EtOIPA in 0.5 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution under dark and light illumination.

elements.content: In conclusion, a hexanuclear zinc cluster based MOF has been synthesized, which exhibits highly enhanced room-temperature phosphorescence compared with the pristine 5-ethoxyisophthalate phosphor ligand. The experiments and calculations indicates that the metal cluster can vastly adjust the molecular conformations, packing arrangement, and photophysical properties of the organic phosphor ligands. The strong coordination bonds between hexanuclear zinc clusters and EtOIPA molecules can afford more dense crystal packing and rigid environment, thus boosting the phosphorescence emission. Meanwhile, the bulky metal cluster can directly affect and tune the photophysical properties of phosphor ligand owing to its heavy atom effect and participation of the frontier orbital distributions. Therefore, this study not only presents a favorable way to control the conformations, packing modes, and electronic structures of phosphor ligands within the MOF matrix but also provides new opportunities to develop phosphorescence MOF materials for potential optoelectronic applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, a hexanuclear zinc cluster based MOF has been synthesized, which exhibits highly enhanced room-temperature phosphorescence compared with the pristine 5-ethoxyisophthalate phosphor ligand. The experiments and calculations indicates that the metal cluster can vastly adjust the molecular conformations, packing arrangement, and photophysical properties of the organic phosphor ligands. The strong coordination bonds between hexanuclear zinc clusters and EtOIPA molecules can afford more dense crystal packing and rigid environment, thus boosting the phosphorescence emission. Meanwhile, the bulky metal cluster can directly affect and tune the photophysical properties of phosphor ligand owing to its heavy atom effect and participation of the frontier orbital distributions. Therefore, this study not only presents a favorable way to control the conformations, packing modes, and electronic structures of phosphor ligands within the MOF matrix but also provides new opportunities to develop phosphorescence MOF materials for potential optoelectronic applications.

elements.content:
PXRD patterns of EtOIPA and Zn-EtOIPA; FT-IR spectra, TGA curve, SEM image and ctrystal structutre of Zn-EtOIPA; conformations of EtOIPA molecule in free EtOIPA and Zn-EtOIPA; phosphorescence spectra and lifetime decay profiles of Zn-EtOIPA in air and oxygen as well as the wet sample; PDFT calculations, cyclic voltammogramsc linear sweep voltammetry curves of of Zn-EtOIPA; time courses of H2 evolution with Zn-EtOIPA photoanode at biases of −1 V vs. Ag/AgCl under light illumination; crystallographic data for Zn-EtOIPA and EtOIPA. The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.9b00450.

(PDF)

The Supporting Information is available free of charge on the ACS Publications website at DOI: 10.1021/acs.inorgchem.9b00450.  (PDF)

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 0.1 mmol, 21.0 mg), Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (0.1 mmol, 22.0 mg), KOH (0.1 mmol, 5.6 mg), and H2O (15 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 72 h, and then cooled to 25 °C over 1 day. Pale-yellow block crystals of Zn-EtOIPA can be isolated.

Synthesis of EtOIPA Crystals

A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 1 mmol, 210 mg) and H2O (8 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 12 h, and then cooled to 25 °C naturally. Colorless block crystals of EtOIPA can be isolated.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Zn-EtOIPA Crystals

A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 0.1 mmol, 21.0 mg), Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (0.1 mmol, 22.0 mg), KOH (0.1 mmol, 5.6 mg), and H2O (15 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 72 h, and then cooled to 25 °C over 1 day. Pale-yellow block crystals of Zn-EtOIPA can be isolated.

Synthesis of EtOIPA Crystals

A mixture of 5-ethoxyisophthalate (EtOIPA, 1 mmol, 210 mg) and H2O (8 mL) was added into a Teflon-lined stainless-steel vessel, kept at a 120 °C constant temperature for 12 h, and then cooled to 25 °C naturally. Colorless block crystals of EtOIPA can be isolated.
